title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Passengers going south from Fort-Wilham or from Oban, arrive at Greenock, or Edinburgh the same day ; may also branch oif at Crianlarich, and proceed by the coaches from Kilhn and Aberfeldy, for Dunkeldand Perth ; or by the mail for Crieff, and the Scottish Cent ral Railway, and arrive at Perth, Stirling, Edinburgh, or Glasgow the same day ; or may land at Inversnaid (on Loch Lomond) for the Trosachs, Callander,  and StirUng.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Passengers going north from Dunkcld, Aberfeldy, Kilhii, and from Crieff, join at Crianlarich for Oban or Fort-William and Inverness.

title: Retrospect of a long life from 1815 to 1883.
author: Hall, S. C.
snippet: pass of Killiecranlde, searching for the spot where was slain the "bloody Dundee" ; heard the "Birks o' Aberfeldy," sung by a bonnie  lassie in the glen and under the fall ; profitably expended hours in the " auld toon " of Edinburgh, and reveled in its history that is romance, and in its romance that is history.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: We gradually strolled into Crichop Linn (a strange high-lying chasmy place, near Closeburn)  ; there pausing, well aloft, and shaded from the noon sun, the two girls, with their father for octave accompaniment, sang us " The Birks of Aberfeldy " so as I have seldom heard a song ; voices excellent and true, especially his voice and native expression given ; which stirred my poor London-severed heart almost to tears.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: So I had Bardolph saddled and rode for Aberfeldy as above said ; home, sunk in manifold murky reflections now lost to me ; and of which only the fewest and friendliest  were comfortably sit for uttering to the Bullers next day.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: " Doesn't this subdue you, Carlyle ?" said he, somewhat solemnly ; we were all three standing at the Falls of Aberfeldy (amid the "Birks" of ditto, and memories of song) silent in the October dusk, perhaps with moon rising — our ten miles to Tiiymouth still ahead — " Doesn't this subdue you ?" " Subdue me ? I should hope not.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: After Aberfeldy cottage the curtain falls.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: I remember baiting him* at Aberfeldy, and to have sate in a kindly and polite yet very huggermugger cottage, among good peasant kirk-people, refreshing themselves, returning home from sermon ; sate for perhaps some two hours, till poor Dolph got rested and refected like his fellow-creatures there.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns:

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: When Queen Victoria was here, anarch was erected on the boundary of the estate, formed of branchesof the birks of Aberfeldy, whereon stood the proud words " Welcome to Breadalbane, Queen Victoria !"The castle is situated a little way from the eastern extremity ofLoch Tay, in one of the most beautiful Highland districts, butwhich the darkness of the evening prevented us from seeing.

snippet: This route proceeds by Aberfeldy, Kenmore, (the noble seat of the noble Marquis of Breadalbane,) from hence to Loch Tay, through Killin to Loch Earn,and then back.
